author: unicronloev

text: "The Giver" Is a man who gives memories of how human life used to take place. The memories are passed down in order to keep them alive while the rest of humanity lives in small communities with everything regulated and controlled to ensure fairness and happiness. Nobody can see color, nor feel strong emotions. Jobs are given based on performance in distinct areas of school, Birth is given by selected individuals and death is not known to anyone. Old people and sick people are "sent off" nobody knows they are being killed.  Now this movie probably makes it look like the Giver isnt supposed to be giving his memories to the boy, but thats exactly what the community wants. The only opposition is when the boy makes a decision to leave the community. He makes that choice after learning about death (from what I remember, correct me if Im wrong)  This movie will probably add a whole bunch of action and explosions when in reality its a quiet book for the most part.

author: Fa Ul

text: I love The Giver and, holy crap -- Jeff Bridges and Meryl Streep?! Brilliant casting. But I have a serious problem...  Why is there color?! If we are seeing the world from Jonas' perspective, why are we -- the audience -- privy to things Jonas cannot even perceive? Or is color not an issue in the movie? And if that's true, then one of the most important moments in the book is missing from the movie. Hell, many important concepts will be missing. What a shame...  Seriously, I haven't read the book in over a decade and I still remember "that moment" VIVIDLY. So sad... maybe they were just afraid of being compared to Pleasantville, which borrows many concepts from The Giver pretty much wholesale.

text: Oh wow finally, I'm glad to see people who aren't hating on this movie just because it's not very much like the book. You should see the other videos of this trailer and their comment sections‚Ä¶they're just riddled with stupid trolls who judge before they think. Also, a lot of people don't know that The Giver is a series, not an individual book. There are three other books in the series: Gathering Blue, Messenger, and Son.¬† Oh, and by the way, the first half of the movie actually is in black and white. They just made this trailer all in color so that people who haven't read the book wouldn't be more confused than they seem to be here.¬†

text: For the people who say The Hunger Games and Divergent are the same: The Hunger Games is about a dystopian future where people are forced to enter their children from 12 to 18 to a fight to the death. Only one will come out alive and they will be crowned victor and live in the victor's village. Katniss Everdeen volunteers in her sister's place to go into the hunger games and she sparks a revolution which turns into a huge war between the Capitol and the districts. Katniss must become the Mockingjay and lead the army as they put an end to their suffering. *SPOILER ALERT IN THE NEXT PART*  Divergent is about a dystopian future which people are separated into 5 different factions: Erudite (the knowledgable) Amity (the kind) Abnegation (the selfless) Dauntless (the brave) and Candor (the honest) People of the world thought a war happened and the faction system helped them but the system is actually just an experiment by a group called Bureau and they send out experiments everywhere in the US to see if people can survive in that kind of system. Tris Prior is Divergent, which means she doesn't belong anywhere but she chooses to be in Dauntless. Tris can't fit in, and the Erudite and some of Dauntless start a war to kill the Divergents because they believe they are a threat to the society. Tris loses a lot during the war but she continues to find out things about the past and discovers more about what the faction system actually meant. Tris and her loved ones (and Peter lol) take it hard. Tris realizes that her divergence was simply a part of the experiment and her whole world was a lie. But there's more to it. The Bureau is planing evil things and Tris must stop it. TOTALLY DIFFERENT, PEOPLE OKAY?

text: "The Giver 2" - Ideas so far.  Jonas enters the house were they are singing carols.  The people greet him and he stands at the back of the room watching as the singing finishes and they hand out presents.  He is told that society is slowly recovering somewhat, but there are bad things still in the world.  At the compound there is chaos as people start encountering their emotions.  The Giver, meanwhile, is taken to the 'Place of Repose' where he is shown the body of the founder of the community which is frozen.  The president (Meryl Streep) said they were instructed to push certain buttons if the community ever came into trouble.  She pushes them, and a host of needles are plunged into the leader, who recovers over the next few days.  The giver is also shown Rosemary's body, who is then resucitated also.  Jonas returns to the compound to see if he can now lead them back into society, but he will encounter a new struggle with the resucitated founder.  He becomes friends with Rosemary.  The founder takes Jonas aside and tells him of an old wager.  Who could rule the world.  His wife established, on the other side of the world, a corresponding compound. When a certain time came to pass, both of them would be resucitated (although it has happened early for the founder) and would compete for reclaiming the world.  As they decide to now do that anyway, towards the end of the second movie they encouter forces of power from the rival compound.  And that is how the second movie ends.  ( My website:  http://noahidebooks.angelfire.com )

text: I keep seeing comments that are like, "No color! Blahhhh!" or, "It's nothing like the movie! Why is it Sci-fi?"  For the Color thing, (somebody already said this, thanks to them. üôÇ) We aren't actually looking out of the perspective of a character, most likely. As for it being kinda Sci-Fi, it is set in the future, like the book. I mean like, I think from the book it could be easy to tell it's in the future, by how there's new sets of ways people live life, and how new things have been invented.  Eh, I'm done. Just kinda bugged of how many comments there are about the dang color and Sci-fi. Anyways,  cya in 2019, years almost ended, huh?

text: 5 years late but whatever this is what is wrong with the movie (never seen the movie but have a read the book and seen the movie trailer)   1. Jonas it supposed to have light eyes. 2. The community is supposed to be black and white (only Jonas and the giver can see colour). 3. The only thing they said was futuristic in the book was the planes in a way that they had a body heat sensor. 4. They are supposed to be Eleven then twelve. 5. No one kissed and Jonas did not tell anybody about the memories (the only thing close to it was the fact he got mad about his friends playing war because of the memory) 6. the thing I'm most mad about.....   THE GIVER TOUCHED HIS BACK TO GIVE MEMORIES NOT HIS WRIST.    ( I'm upset that the actors do not look twelve)  (I'm also upset that Taylor swift is rosemary no hate to Taylor but not who I pictured rosemary to be/look like.)
